pullRequest.body:
This PR proves that `Nat.bitwise` (from core) and `Nat.bitwise'` (from mathlib) are equal

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

This proof has been extracted from #5920, and follows the advice from https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/5920#discussion_r1321066176

nodes.body:
The proofs have now been cleaned up, and the linter should be happy.

I also went a bit further and completely removed `Nat.bitwise'` in #7451
maintainer merge
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by ChrisHughes24.

:v: alexkeizer can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+
Canceled.
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6458656396/job/17532805200)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6458656396/job/17532805677)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6458656396/job/17532805939)

Nice results!

bors d+

Does `bitwise'_bit` already exist?

Can you write the types of `a m b n` explicitly?
`bitwise'_bit` exists, but has `f false false = false` as assumption, we replace that assumption with `(ham : m = 0 ‚Üí a = true)` and `(hbn : n = 0 ‚Üí b = true)` for `bitwise'_bit'`.
Instead of using `next`, can you use `\.` markers for each goal?

```suggestion
lemma div2_add_two (x) :
    div2 (x + 2) = div2 x + 1 := by
```
because `x + 2` is not syntactically `succ (succ x)`

Does something like this work, and save the need for the `have`?
```suggestion
  induction' hk : x + y using Nat.strongInductionOn with k ih generalizing x y
```
It does
You shouldn't be unfolding `bitwise` here: if you need to unfold it, that means a simpler lemma (where `unfold` is fine) is missing.

Which is to say: we should probably have the lemmas:
* `bitwise_zero_left : bitwise f 0 m = if f false true then m else 0`
* `bitwise_zero_right : bitwise f n 0 = if f true false then n else 0`
* `bitwise_of_ne_zero (n \ne 0) (m \ne 0) : ...` (from the last branch of the definition, replacing the `if` with `bit`)

I've cleaned up the proof. Turns out we also needed `bitwise'_zero_right : bitwise' f m 0 = if f true false then m else 0`.
This result exists in `Mathlib.Init.Data.Nat.Bitwise`, but it has `f false false = false` as an assumption.
I've added an alternative theorem with a proof that does not need this assumption, but instead relies on `eq_mpr_eq_cast` from `Mathlib.Logic.Basic`.

This duplication seems undesirable, but my understanding is that `Init` files sould not depend on non-`Init` files.
Then again, do we even need this result in `Init.Data.Nat.Bitwise`? I would guess it's a historic artifact from lean3 where these definitions were the main way to interact with `Nat`s.
I think most of the `Mathlib.Init` files are vestigial from lean3, and moving things out of them is totally fine
This statement looks pretty awkward to me, especially as a `simp` lemma. I think taking `h : n ‚â† 0` would be better?

I changed it to be in terms of `succ` exactly because it felt cleaner to have a `simp` lemma without side-conditions, but you are right that the actual statement is not very clean. I'll trust your judgement on which one is better

```suggestion
lemma bitwise_of_ne_zero {n m : Nat} (hn : n ‚â† 0) (hm : m ‚â† 0) :
```
Is the naming convention; your name suggests the *conclusion* is `‚â† 0`
Fixed

Is there a reason to use `by rfl` over `rfl`: could you leave a comment explaining why? Or can this simply be:
```suggestion
lemma bitwise_zero_left {m : Nat} : bitwise f 0 m = if f false true then m else 0 :=
  rfl
```

I default to `by rfl` because it's [supposedly faster](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/270676-lean4/topic/What.20is.20the.20elaborator.20doing.20in.20this.20example) than `rfl` as a term, but the latter would also work.
You should prefer `rfl` unless you have evidence that the speed matters (ie, the file becomes painful to edit)

What is the motivation for writing it like this, instead of (from the top of my head):
```suggestion
    bit (f (bodd n) (bodd m)) (bitwise f (n / 2) (m / 2)) := by
```
It seems like `bit` is not simplified further normally, so we should use it as the `simp`-normal form.

The motivation was that `bitwise` is not implemented in terms of `bit`, but instead as
```
    let n' := n / 2
    let m' := m / 2
    let b‚ÇÅ := n % 2 = 1
    let b‚ÇÇ := m % 2 = 1
    let r  := bitwise f n' m'
    if f b‚ÇÅ b‚ÇÇ then
      r+r+1
    else
      r+r
```

However, that should be equal to just `bit`, and I do agree that reads nicer, so I'll change it

Similarly:
```suggestion
lemma bitwise'_of_ne_zero {n m : Nat} (hn : n ‚â† 0) (hm : m ‚â† 0) :
    bitwise' f n m =
    bit (f (bodd n)) (f (bodd m)) (bitwise' f (n / 2) (m / 2)) := by
```
(Also replacing `div2` with `. / 2`, following [Nat.div2_val](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Init/Data/Nat/Bitwise.html#Nat.div2_val).)
Are you suggesting that `div2_val` should be `simp` too?
I'm inclined to say yes, but perhaps the optimizer (`csimp` right?) should go the other way.
`csimp` can only turn `foo a b` into `bar a b`, not `foo a b` into `bar_a b`.

Whether `div2_val` is or isn't `simp` does not influence the optimizer, right? So I guess that is orthogonal to the current PR.
Should I mark `div2_val` as `simp` here, or leave that to a different PR with more thorough discussion/review? I'd like to merge this one ASAP
I think you should make the change Anne suggested above, and make `div2_val` simp if it makes things easier for you
I made the change. Making `div2_val` `simp` or not does not change things for me, so I left it at the status quo (not `simp`)

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: prove equality of `Nat.bitwise` and `Nat.bitwise'`
